ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MINDEF WORK YEAR FOR IN-CAMP TRAINING
(Adjustment of Schedule)


    1. Mr Yeo Guat Kwang asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence whether it is possible to adjust the MINDEF Work Year for In-Camp Training (ICT) to commence from January instead of March each year, to be in line with the calendar year so as to reduce disruptions to our operationally ready National Servicemen's civilian work schedules, particularly the application for leave and absence from work due to ICT, as they are based on the calendar year.

     The Second Minister for Defence (RAdm Teo Chee Hean) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the MINDEF Work Year, like all other Government Ministries, is pegged to the financial year from 1st April to end March of the following year. All SAF activities, courses and programmes are therefore pegged to the same time

Column: 1064

frame for the reason of budgeting and allocation of training resources. The SAF yearly in-camp training schedule is finalised by September each year, which gives a six-month lead time before the commencement of the next work year. This allows the SAF to give at least six months advance notice to NSmen who would be called up in the next work year, which extends from April to the end of March. There is sufficient notice for NSmen to make leave applications and to inform their employers.

    I also wish to point out that to change the in-camp training work year to a calendar year rather than a financial year will also not, of course, reduce the number of call-ups. However, MINDEF will have a relook at Mr Yeo's suggestion to see whether there is any real merit and benefit in doing this.

INCREASES IN FOOD PRICES BY HAWKERS


    2. Mr Yeo Guat Kwang asked the Minister for the Environment what actions are being taken to prevent hawkers from taking unwarranted advantage of the recent increases in water charges and public transport fares to increase their prices.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, the food retailing business is a highly competitive one. There are some 20,000 stalls in hawker centres and another 12,000 stalls in eating houses and other private establishments. Competition between this large number of stalls has helped to keep food prices reasonable and affordable. Most hawkers are good businessmen and know from experience that overcharging will result in lower demand and loss of goodwill.

    Hawkers are required to display price tags at their stalls. Consumers can decide for themselves whether or not to patronise a particular stall. This is the best way to ensure that food prices remain reasonable and prevent any unscrupulous hawker from taking unwarranted advantage of the recent increases in water charges and public transport fares.

Column: 1065



    However, we must also be fair to hawkers. As our economy continues to grow at a healthy pace, Singapore workers will continue to enjoy good annual wage increases. Hawkers, too, would like to have their earnings keep pace with that of other Singaporeans. We must therefore not begrudge them their price increases, provided these are kept reasonable.

Column: 1065

CENTRAL EXPRESSWAY
(Easing of traffic congestion on roads in vicinity)


    3. Mr Yeo Guat Kwang asked the Minister for Communications what plans are being made to ease the traffic congestion on roads in the vicinity of the Central Expressway which motorists use as alternative ways to their destinations so as to avoid the Electronic Road Pricing System on the main highway.

     The Minister of State for Communications (Dr John Chen Seow Phun) (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) has not been implemented yet, I suppose the Member is referring to the Road Pricing Scheme (RPS) on the CTE in the Question.

    The main alternative roads to CTE are Upper Serangoon Road and Upper Thomson Road. Work is in progress to build a three-tiered interchange at the junction of Upper Serangoon Road and Braddell Road. When completed in 1999, it will improve traffic flow along Upper Serangoon Road. In the meantime, LTA has made adjustments to the traffic light timing at some junctions along these roads to improve the traffic flow.

    However, motorists must realise that the objective of the RPS is to ease the congestion along our key expressways and arterial roads and to provide them with a choice of fast transit by paying an appropriate fee. Motorists too must play their part. It is difficult to expect both the expressways and alternate routes to have light traffic at peak hours, unless more of those who are unwilling to pay the RPS charges and are unhappy with the heavier

Column: 1066

traffic along alternate routes, choose other options. These other options include taking public transport, park and ride, car-pooling, or changing their time of travel.

    When the RPS scheme was extended to the expressways on 5th May, the public transport operators introduced four new express bus services to provide motorists using the expressways another option. Public response to these four new express bus services has been encouraging, with ridership more than doubling since service began.

    The park and ride scheme allows the commuters easier connection to the MRT or public bus system and helps reduce their transport costs. It is another good alternative to driving. To-date, out of the 3,759 car parks available, 731 or 19.4% has been taken up. We have received feedback that the current time limit of 8.00 pm is a constraint as some commuters are unable to return to their cars before 8.00 pm due to work commitments. I am therefore pleased to announce that Transit Link, the operator of the park and ride scheme, will extend the weekday parking hours by one hour from 7.00 am to 9.00 pm with effect from 1st August 1997. This move should encourage more motorists to make use of the park and ride scheme.

     Mr R. Sinnakaruppan (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State what is the rationale for ALS label holders using the CTE in the mornings being charged additional fees under the RPS while ALS holders using the PIE and the ECP are not charged?

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, this was the concession that LTA gave to full-day ALS holders using CTE until 1st July 1997. The reason why we have to withdraw the concession is that almost 80% of those who travelled along the CTE held the full-day ALS pass. That contributed to the congestion. In order to alleviate the congestion, we have to withdraw that concession so that those who pay for the $2 RPS pass would enjoy the benefit of free-flowing traffic along the CTE. In the past, they did not have to pay even a cent. Now they have to pay $2.

Column: 1067



     Mr Sinnakaruppan: Would the Minister consider extending this concession to the CTE users until July 1998?

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: No, the concession was given on 5th May when RPS was extended to the CTE. Because of the concession, the scheme was not effective enough to reduce congestion. That is why the Ministry has decided to withdraw that concession and motorists using CTE are required to pay for the $2 RPS pass.

     Dr Toh See Kiat (Aljunied): Will the Minister of State review the system now that it has become so effective that there is hardly any congestion on the CTE?

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, the result of this refinement is a positive one. The average speed during the restricted hours has moved from 25 kph before RPS to slightly above 60 kph. That is the target that we are reaching. Of course, we are mindful that if we overcharge, it would result in under-utilisation of the expressways, and that is not good. Our target is at least 55 kph. And we are quite happy with the range from 55 kph to 65 kph.

     Mr Ong Kian Min (Pasir Ris): Sir, I would like to join my fellow GPC members in speaking about providing facilities to promote community bonding. Please allow me to illustrate with a resident living in Pasir Ris. This resident comes back

Column: 1068

from work and as he walks from the bus stop or the multi-storey car park to his block, he enjoys the quietness and residential feel of his neighbourhood which has been developed on the precinct concept. He passes the linked building and remembers the RC block party held there two Sundays ago where he had the opportunity to meet many other residents and made some new friends. The linked building is spacious and very useful for organised activities such as block parties and ceremonies. However, that day, being a week day, the linked building is bare and empty and is used by some children playing football.

    He passes the RC centre which occupies the Civil Defence bomb shelter. The layout of the CD shelter does not encourage him to venture in and he is too shy to simply walk in and say that he wishes to get to know more people. Unlike the coffeeshops and provision shops in the older housing estates where people can meet other people, there are no such outlets within his precinct. As there is nothing to cause him to linger, he heads straight for his home and shuts the door behind him. Thereafter, he is isolated from the rest of his community. Somehow, he feels a sense of loneliness and misses the hustle and bustle usually associated with the older housing estates like Toa Payoh where he was living with his parents before he moved to Pasir Ris.

    Sir, I believe what we need are conducive communal meeting points within the precinct that encourages residents to come together spontaneously to socialise and interact around common interests. It would add so much more to the concept of living as a community if residents come back to their precinct and find a conglomerate of family activities revolving around what I would term as a family activity centre. I envisage such a centre to be a cross between the Officers' Mess in the army camps, the students' lounge in the university campus, the mini clubhouse of a private condominium and the increasingly popular coffee clubs. It does not have to be a big or spacious centre. But it should have a snacks corner serving food, tea and even specially brewed coffee where residents

Column: 1069

could meet casually, and next to it, could be a reading room with magazines sponsored by Singapore Press Holdings. In an adjoining room, there could be a children's adventure nook, art and craft niche, music corner or hobby centre. Outside, there could be a children's playground.

    These family activity centres could be built as an extension to the existing RC centre or they can be purpose-built at a suitable location, for example, next to the PCF education centre, community children's library or childcare centres. In any case, these centres should be strategically located for residents to come together informally to trade stories and share experiences. They should be open and readily available, a place where residents can call their own, where they can gravitate to, whenever they have some time, a home away from home where they can feel at ease, where they can always find good company.

    Sir, I would like to raise this with the Ministry of National Development for consideration. Because I feel that once the physical structures are built, the residents themselves, with the RCs acting as the catalyst, can arrange for activities that appeal to their particular community.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, the Interim Upgrading Programme (IUP) is a very well-received exercise for residents in HDB estates. The Government has recently increased the allocation to $7,000 per household.

    One popular item in the IUP is to provide for new lifts to land on every floor. This provision of lifts to stop at every floor is needed by the old folks, the handicapped and young children. The problem is that new lifts are quite expensive, and different precincts have different requirements for lifts. In most IUPs, lift upgrading is usually given the top priority. The remaining funds are then assigned for other improvement works in the precincts. In some old estates with tall blocks, a situation may arise where most of the funds are used to provide for

Column: 1070

lift upgrading. Little money is left for other improvement works which are also necessary, such as linkways, lobby area upgrading and landscaping.

    I would like to suggest that the Ministry of National Development consider splitting the IUP in two portions. One portion is for funding of lift upgrading and another portion for funding of other requirements. The first portion for lift upgrading should be funded entirely by MND, while the second portion may be based on a dollar value per household. This two-portion formula will be more equitable as all precincts will receive the same allocation per household for upgrading of the common areas, other than lifts.

    As upgrading of lifts under the IUP is a very popular and critical item, I hope the Minister will consider this proposal favourably.

     Mr Sinnakaruppan: Sir, I join my Chairman of the GPC in asking for a lift upgrading programme.

    Sir, in estates that are 14 years and older, the lifts are the old design and they are very, very slow. These lifts have a speed of about 45 metres per minute compared to the latest HDB lifts that are up to 120 metres per minute, in other words three times faster. Not only that, some of these lifts have an old relay control such that when a user presses for a lift, both the adjacent lifts come up to the floor of the user. As a result, many other residents have to wait much longer to get on to the lifts. Some of my residents tell me that they have to wait as long as five minutes before they get on to the lift and take them several minutes more to get on to the ground floor. Worse still, some of these lifts break down often and on several occasions during my house-to-house visits, my grassroots leaders and I have been trapped in some of these lifts. And, of course, the biggest complaints come from the older residents who want lift landing on every floor.

    Sir, the present HDB's lift replacement cycle is 28 years. This is certainly far too long, especially in relation to the rapid advances in lift technology. It is like

Column: 1071

trying to use a 286 computer until the computer cannot boot up any more, totally inefficient and obsolete.

    Luckily for residents, HDB allows lift replacement during IUP from Batch 4 onwards. But what about those precincts that were upgraded in the first Batch, the second Batch and the third Batch? It will take a long time before they get their Main Upgrading Programme. What about those estates that have yet to be selected for IUP or MUP?

    Sir, therefore, I would like to propose to the Minister to introduce a new scheme for upgrading of lifts that are 14 years and above, and which are not identified for IUP or MUP. As the Lift Upgrading Programme can be done much faster than the IUP or MUP, it will certainly benefit residents, especially the older residents who would benefit from having lift landing on every floor. The HDB funding must certainly be adequate for the Town Councils to embark on it. Like Mr Leong Horn Kee, I would like to suggest that the funding for the IUP incorporating the lift upgrading be increased. Presently, only $1,000 per household is allocated for this purpose, and this accounts for about 15% of the total funding. My estimates for one of the precincts in my estate suggest that you need to provide for about $3,500 per household unit in order to do the lift upgrading, so that there is sufficient fund for other enhancements in the precinct and to do the repainting works. Therefore, I would like to suggest to the Minister to increase the funding for IUP from the present $7,000 to $9,500 per household.

    Sir, finally, on another point. The Minister, in his reply to Mr Ang Mong Seng's request to install lifts in four-storey flats, had agreed to do so during the MUP for such flats. I would like to request the Minister to go one step further and allow this to be done in the IUP as well.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (East Coast): Sir, like my colleagues before me, I rise in support of this issue on lift upgrading. This was raised by me in a Question for Oral Answer just last week. The Minister had indicated that we are spending close to $170 million a year on lift upgrading.

Column: 1072

Therefore, politically, I see that it benefits both the Government and the people. We can show that the asset enhancement scheme is now extended to a new scheme called the Lift Upgrading Programme. After all, $170 million is not small beer.

    By having the lift upgrading programme in a separate scheme, we can then target the precincts or the flats which require such upgrading. For example, in the current Interim Upgrading Programme in my estate, the latest batch, there are nine blocks of flats which qualify for interim upgrading, but only four blocks of flats can reasonably be done with the funds provided under the IUP for upgrading the lifts. But the other five blocks of flats just cannot be done because of the way the flats were designed and structured. It will cost a lot of money. Because the estates are not homogenous, it is almost impossible to have lift upgrading to be spread all over the precinct under the current IUP scheme.

    As we all know, almost all new flats do have lifts that stop on every floor. There is a lift landing on every floor. Obviously, this is a very popular item. The irony of it is that most of the flats which require some form of upgrading usually have older folks or senior citizens living in those estates as the younger ones tend to move into new estates where there is lift landing on every floor. But it is the older estates which are the ones where lift upgrading has to be done. I really urge the Minister to consider creating a separate programme called the Lift Upgrading Programme on top of the MUP and the IUP.

     Mr Ong Kian Min: Sir, I would like to commend the Ministry of National Development and the Housing and Development Board for their good work in continually improving the design and finish of HDB flats. The improvement is so significant that there is a vast difference between flats that are 10 years old and those that are built even five years after that. One difference stands out, and that is, the new flats are provided with lifts that serve every floor. In Pasir Ris South division of Pasir Ris GRC, there is a mix

Column: 1073

of older blocks where the lifts do not stop at every floor and newer blocks where the lifts do. A number of residents from the older blocks have told me that with the newer flats having reached five years' old and coming onto the resale market, prospective purchasers are no longer interested even to consider the older flats as these are not served directly by lifts. Purchasers naturally prefer flats with direct same floor access to the lifts.

    Under the revised IUP programme, the Government has increased its IUP funding from $6,000 per unit to $7,000 per unit for those blocks which incorporated full lift upgrading in their works. I do not think this funding is sufficient for older slab blocks where there are common corridors only on certain floors. Units at the two sides of the block which are not served by the central lift well can only be accessible by way of a common corridor and the stairs. The solution is therefore not as simple as punching holes in the central lift well and upgrading the lift mechanism to stop at every floor. For such blocks, separate lift wells may have to be constructed at huge cost. I would like to join my hon. colleagues in asking the Minister to consider implementing a separate comprehensive programme on lift upgrading, so that residents of older HDB flats will benefit from the latest improvement in HDB design and our standard of living.

     Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay (Chua Chu Kang): Sir, ever since the Government announced the measures to cool property speculation, the price of residential property is stable and some show signs of declining. The demand has fallen and the property in the low end shows that HDB upgraders are the main buyers. The outcome of the anti-speculation measures is anticipated. When the property speculators are wiped out from the market, the subsequent demand will be genuine, and the market will then take some time, perhaps a few years, to adjust itself to a price level which is acceptable and suitable.

Column: 1074



    Comparing the price index, today's price of the private residential property is about 2.55 times the price in the third quarter in 1991. Though the price shows a 3.7% dip in the first quarter of this year, the present price is still more than 2.45 times the price in 1991. How far the current price should be readjusted is a question that nobody could answer. Based on the 1985 experience, the downward adjustment of the price could be as much as 40% below the price at the peak.

    In Singapore's residential property market, the main bulk of supply is from a handful of big developers. As long as they believe that the Government will come out to support the property market if the price should drop significantly, they will continue to bid high in the Government's land sales. They know that as long as the market does not collapse, the tendered land price will be eventually paid by the buyer.

    There are good reasons why people believe that the Government will come out to support the market. First, the Government is the largest land owner. Second, the Government is also the largest developer who supplies more than half of the quantity of residential units through its public housing programme. The collapse of the private housing market will depress the construction industry which has approximately 10% share in our GDP, and it will be reflected in our economic growth figures.

    I feel that the Government should allow the market to settle itself to a new level without much interference. Otherwise, it will be misunderstood by the people that we really have an interest in the market to jack up the price. What we should do is to have a long-term view on the property prices. They should reaffirm the long-term commitment of the Government on the announcement that 30% of residential property is for private housing and the remaining 70% is for public housing. In order to achieve this objective, the Government should continue to supply adequate land and the targeted people for those 30% of private property should have an income level which is comfortable enough

Column: 1075

to own a private property. In other words, the long-term price of a private property must be affordable.

    Look at the current stock of the residential property. The estimated numbers are about 730,000 units for public housing and about 150,000 for private residential units. In other words, the present private residential housing is about 17% of the total. If public housing is still committed to 25,000 to 30,000 units per annum, and the 30% target for private housing is to be achieved in the long term, say, 20 years from now, the supply of private houses or flats per year will be around 13,000 units. This is a very huge figure. It will not be achievable if Government does not continue to supply a significant number of land sites through its land sale programme.

    I urge the Government to look into the long-term supply of land, instead of playing with the current supply, to deal with the short-term fluctuations of property prices.

    Sir, the next issue is the affordability of the people who will be the potential buyers of private properties. Let us assume that a household uses 30% of its monthly disposable income, and all in CPF contributions, as monthly instalments for housing loan. If the loan is 70% of the property price, repayment is 25 years, and based on current interest rate of 6%, according to the 1990 Population Census of a couple's income, ie, husband's and wife's income, and the annual increase of income was 5% per annum, calculated until today's date, at the entry point to the top 10% of the couples' income, they could only afford a house or flat of $840,000. For those couple's income at the entry point of the top 16%, they could only afford a flat costing $633,000. If the built-up area for this kind of flat is about 1,100 sq ft, the affordable price will be around $575 per sq ft. If we really wish the top 20%, or 30%, of the couple's income, who can afford to own this 30% of the potential private residential housing, the current price is still considered too high. I would like to urge the Government to study the long-term pricing of private

Column: 1076

property and hope that, with some appropriate measure, private property will be affordable for the potential local buyers.
1.00 pm

     Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, I am speaking on the upgrading of private estates, not on the private residential market. This request for the Government's assistance to help upgrade private estates is a regular item raised by MPs during the yearly Committee of Supply debate, particularly by MPs with large private residential populations, such as Mr Sinnakaruppan, Mr Lew Syn Pau and myself.

    Compared to the HDB residents, some private estates, especially the old ones, are becoming like their poor cousins. In HDB estates, the residents enjoy upgrading programmes like IUP and MUP. For the fortunate some, they even get cash grants under the SERS programme. Private estates so far get nothing.

    There have been constant calls to look into upgrading of private estates. I am not suggesting that the upgrading of private estates be similar to the MUP in HDB estates where the blocks and their interiors are upgraded. For private estates, the upgrading need only be similar to the IUP concept. The estate can be provided with a grant amounting to a certain dollar value per household. If we use a figure of just $5,000 per household (less than the HDB's IUP provision of $7,000 per household), then an estate with 100 units may receive about $500,000 to upgrade the common areas in their estate. This sum is quite meaningful. The grant can be used for improvement of common areas and provision of recreational facilities, such as playgrounds, linkways, clubhouse upgrading, barbeque pits and landscaping.

    I would like to suggest that the selection criteria for eligible private estates for this grant can also be based on some criteria similar to the HDB estates, like age of the estate, whether they have community spirit and whether they have active and responsible area committees. I recall that the Government has previously formed a Committee under Mr Matthias Yao, the

Column: 1077

former Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development, to study this matter. May I ask the Minister what is the status of the study.

    I believe MPs will continue to raise this proposal until we get a satisfactory answer.
